repnme.cdata!:
Bosnia and Herzegovina, Moldova, and Serbia
            - Transport and Trade Facilitation in Southeast Europe Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The World Bank's Southeastern
            Europe Trade and Transport Facilitation Program (TTFSE or
            the program) was a regional initiative covering projects for
            eight countries (Albania, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Bulgaria,
            Croatia, Macedonia, Moldova, Romania, and Serbia) between
            2000 and 2007, in the context of international initiatives
            to help restore the economic linkages among these countries
            and bring them closer to the European Union. The two
            interrelated objectives were to: (i) reduce non-tariff costs
            of trade and transport; and (ii) reduce smuggling and
            corruption. This report assesses the program as a whole,
            based in part on an evaluation of the three projects more
            recently completed (Bosnia-Herzegovina, Moldova, Serbia) and
            in part on other evidence from the other five projects and
            the Southeast Europe region. This summary assesses the TTFSE
            program as a whole, the evaluation of the three projects is
            presented in annexes A, B, and C.

repnme.cdata!:
Bosnia and Herzegovina - Trade and
            Transport Facilitation in Southeast Europe Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Trade and Transport Facilitation in
            Southeast Europe Project for Bosnia and Herzegovina had the
            following ratings: the outcome was satisfactory, the
            sustainability was likely, the institutional development
            impact was substantial, and the Bank and borrower
            performance were both satisfactory. Following are some of
            the lessons learned: The economic returns from such
            replication in BiH could be considerable, multiplying the
            economic returns to date by several times. Trade
            facilitation is always a multi-sectoral and multi-agency
            activity. Customs control is expected to become more
            effective and efficient under streamlined procedures, based
            on selectivity and risk analysis. Further cooperation and
            commitment from government agencies, especially in the area
            of updating data in website are essential to make the
            regional website sustainable and successful. It is important
            to continue the modernization of procedures at all border
            stations using as much as possible the rules and
            recommendations of the revised Convention on the
            simplification and harmonization of Customs procedures.
            While constructing border crossing facilities, innovative
            designs that allow future conversion into logistic centers,
            warehouses, etc, must be encouraged. The long lines of
            vehicles waiting to be processed at border crossing points
            are symptomatic of the need for trade facilitation. Building
            a tradition of inter-agency communication and information
            sharing as well as building the mechanisms on which such
            communication can be based, needs a high-level government
            commitment and ideally a champion. Cumbersome visa
            procedures and requirements for professional drivers are
            slowing down especially road freight transport.

repnme.cdata!:
Bosnia and Herzegovina - Trade and
            Transport Facilitation in Southeast Europe Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Trade and Transport Facilitation in
            Southeast Europe Project for Bosnia and Herzegovina, aims at
            modernizing, and strengthening customs administrations, and
            border control agencies, in a collaborative effort between
            the regional Governments, the European Union, the United
            States, and the Bank. Its main objectives are to reduce
            non-tariff costs to trade and transport, and, to reduce
            smuggling, and corruption at border crossings. The
            components include: 1) construction of buildings, and
            canopies at the Raca border crossing, and an inland truck
            terminal (Novi Grad). Additionally, weighing scales, and
            laboratory equipment will be supplied, including the
            corresponding training. Technical services should monitor
            the performance of the country's Customs
            Administration, while training to enhance inter-agency
            awareness will be provided; 2) construction of border
            stations at Izacic, and Orasje, reconstruction of inland
            terminals, and information technology infrastructure.
            Technical services will monitor the performance of the
            Federation Customs Administration, while training should
            enhance inter-agency cooperation; 3) conventional, and
            distance learning training in logistics, and, international
            freight transport, in cooperation with international
            professional associations. Public-private partnerships will
            be enhanced using a virtual forum, to facilitate trade
            development; and, 4) regional, and national services,
            supported by advisors in procurement, accounting, and
            external auditing, including the establishment of a
            financial management system, and training for project
            management, and implementation.

repnme.cdata!:
Bosnia and Herzegovina - Trade and
            Transport Facilitation in Southeast Europe : environmental
            management plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The review of the project components for
            the Trade and Transportation Facilitation in Southeast
            Europe Project for Bosnia and Herzegovina indicated that the
            project is unlikely to have significant adverse
            environmental impacts and is accordingly confirmed as a
            category B project. To prevent, minimize, or mitigate site
            specific negative impacts, however, this environmental
            management plan (EMP) and a set of mitigation measures have
            been prepared. The major concerns about possible negative
            site specific impacts associated with border crossings
            relate to 1) emissions from vehicles waiting for custom
            clearances; 2) drainage of disinfectants and spills of oils
            and fuel; 3) waste disposal and loose garbage; and 4) site
            disruptions caused by upgrades or relocations of utilities
            or such infrastructure as buildings, parking/waiting areas,
            and access roads. Specific actions to minimize any
            potentially negative impact and promote institutional
            development include liaising with environmental authorities
            and reviewing and monitoring EMP compliance; staff training
            and sensitization at each border crossing; certifying
            acceptable practices and impact minimization, especially
            storing and properly using disinfecting materials and
            chemicals, and hazardous materials and garbage; harmonizing
            regulatory requirements with European Union and
            international standards; and incorporating environmental
            plans in consultant contracts and project design.
